bottleneck_addressed: Distribution — total invisibility to target market + generic positioning
total_time_budget: 10-12 hours/week (estimated for solo founder, likely part-time)

experiments.name: The Barbershop Blitz — 20 in-person demos in 30 days
experiments.hypothesis: If we demo Timber face-to-face in 20 local barbershops, then at least 5 will sign up for a free trial, because barbers buy through trust and personal relationships, not websites
steps: 1. Identify 30 independent barbershops within 30 minutes of your location (Google Maps, Yelp)
2. Prioritise 1-3 chair shops (owner-operated, most likely to adopt new tools)
3. Walk in during a quiet time (Tuesday-Wednesday, 10-11am or 2-3pm)
4. Ask: 'Hey, I built a booking app — can I show you for 2 minutes? No pressure.'
5. Demo on your phone/tablet: show how a client books without downloading anything
6. If interested: set them up on the 14-day trial right there
7. Get their phone number for follow-up regardless of outcome
8. Ask: 'What booking tool do you use now? What do you hate about it?'
9. Log every conversation: objections, current tool, interest level, feedback
experiments.kill_criteria: If after 10 demos, 0 barbers showed any interest or all said 'I already use Fresha/Square and I'm happy', the product positioning needs fundamental rework.
experiments.risk: Founder may be uncomfortable with cold in-person outreach. Barbers may be too busy to listen. Could get 20 rejections.
experiments.expected_outcome: 5-8 free trial signups, 20 logged conversations revealing real objections and needs. This data is worth more than 6 months of Reddit posting.
experiments.minimum_viable_version: Demo at 5 barbershops this week. If any show interest, continue to 20.

experiments.name: Facebook Group Immersion — become a known face in barber communities
experiments.hypothesis: If we actively engage in 3-5 Facebook barber groups for 4 weeks (helping, not selling), then barbers will start asking about Timber organically when we subtly mention it, because Facebook groups are the #1 community for barber software recommendations
steps: 1. Join 5 Facebook barber groups: Barber Nation, Barbers Talk, Black Barber Connect, Salon Owners Club, Booth Renters & Suite Owners
2. For the first 2 weeks: ONLY help. Answer questions about booking, business tips, no-show strategies. Zero product mentions.
3. Week 3: When someone asks 'what booking app should I use?', mention Timber naturally with the differentiator: 'I built one where clients don't need to download anything — happy to show you'
4. Week 4: Share a short video showing the client booking experience (10 seconds, no app download)
5. Track: DMs received, questions asked, trial signups from Facebook referrals
experiments.kill_criteria: If after 4 weeks of genuine engagement, zero barbers show interest in the product when mentioned, the value proposition may not resonate with this audience.

skills_needed: barber industry knowledge (learn as you go)

experiments.risk: Getting banned for self-promotion if too aggressive. Being ignored if the groups are inactive. Takes discipline to help-first for 2 weeks.
experiments.expected_outcome: Establishes founder as a genuine community participant. 2-5 interested barbers. Deep understanding of what barbers actually talk about and need.
experiments.minimum_viable_version: Join 2 groups, post 3 helpful comments this week. See if anyone engages.

experiments.name: Directory Blitz — get listed everywhere in one weekend
experiments.hypothesis: If we list Timber on G2, Capterra, GetApp, AlternativeTo, Product Hunt, SaaSHub, and BetaList, then we'll generate 50+ website visits and 2-3 signups per month from directory traffic, because these are where businesses actively compare booking software
steps: 1. Create accounts on G2, Capterra, GetApp, Software Advice, AlternativeTo, SaaSHub, BetaList
2. Write a compelling listing: lead with 'no app download for clients' differentiator
3. Add screenshots, logo, pricing info, feature list
4. List as alternative to: Fresha, Booksy, Square Appointments, Vagaro
5. Ask your 1 existing user to leave a review on G2 and Capterra
6. Plan a Product Hunt launch for Week 4 (after you have 3-5 users for social proof)
experiments.kill_criteria: Directories are a set-and-forget channel. No kill criteria — just maintain listings.
experiments.risk: Low — this is table-stakes marketing that should have been done at launch. Only risk is if listings get rejected for being too new/thin.
experiments.expected_outcome: Permanent passive discovery channel. Won't drive massive traffic alone but builds credibility and backlinks.
experiments.minimum_viable_version: List on G2 and Capterra this weekend. Add others next week.

experiments.name: Homepage Rewrite — lead with the differentiator
experiments.hypothesis: If we rewrite the homepage to lead with 'Your clients book in 10 seconds — no app download, no signup' instead of generic 'easiest booking software', then click-to-signup conversion will increase from ~6% to 15%+, because the no-download angle is the one genuine differentiator that resonates with the barber pain point
steps: 1. New headline: 'Your clients shouldn't need an app just to book a haircut.'
2. Sub-headline: 'Timber lets clients book in 10 seconds — no download, no signup. Just pick a time.'
3. Add a 15-second demo GIF showing the client booking experience
4. Add social proof (even if it's just '14-day free trial — join X barbers')
5. Clear CTA: 'Try free for 14 days — set up in 5 minutes'
6. Remove or deprioritise generic feature lists
7. A/B test if possible; otherwise just ship and measure before/after
experiments.kill_criteria: If conversion doesn't improve after 100+ visitors, the differentiator may not be compelling enough for homepage visitors.
experiments.risk: Low — the current homepage isn't converting, so almost any change is an improvement.
experiments.expected_outcome: Better conversion of the small traffic that does arrive. Sets up all other experiments for better funnel performance.
experiments.minimum_viable_version: Change just the headline and sub-headline. Takes 30 minutes.

experiments.name: Instagram Proof-of-Concept — show the product in action
experiments.hypothesis: If we create an Instagram account and post 3 short Reels per week showing the booking experience from a client's perspective, then we'll gain 200+ followers and 5+ DMs from barbers in 6 weeks, because barbers live on Instagram and short-form video is their native content format
steps: 1. Create @timberpos (or better: @timberbooking) Instagram account
2. Film 10-second screen recordings: client opens link → picks time → done. No download.
3. Add text overlay: 'This is what YOUR clients see. No app. No signup. 10 seconds.'
4. Use hashtags: #barberlife #barbershop #barbersoftware #barberbusiness #barberbooking
5. Engage with barber content — comment genuinely on barber posts (not pitching)
6. DM barbers who post about booking frustrations (gently, not spammy)
7. Post 3x/week: booking demo, barber business tip, client experience
experiments.kill_criteria: If after 6 weeks and 18+ posts, total engagement is under 50 likes and 0 DMs, Instagram may not be the right format for this product demo.
experiments.risk: Content creation takes time. Barbers may not follow a software account. Need to find the right content angle.
experiments.expected_outcome: Instagram becomes a warm outreach channel and social proof mechanism. Barbers who see the product working are more likely to try it.
experiments.minimum_viable_version: Post 1 Reel this week showing the client booking flow. See if any barbers engage.

experiments.name: The First Paying Customer — convert free users to paid
experiments.hypothesis: If we personally call/visit the existing free user(s) and offer a deeply discounted first 3 months ($10/month), then at least 1 will convert to paid, because the product is solving a real problem for them and the price barrier is minimal
steps: 1. Contact every free user personally — phone call or in-person visit preferred
2. Ask: 'What do you love about Timber? What's missing? What would make you pay?'
3. Offer: 'I'd love to keep building this for barbers like you. Would $10/month for the first 3 months work? You'd be my first paying customer and I'll prioritise your feedback.'
4. If they say no: ask 'What would need to change for this to be worth paying for?'
5. If they say yes: celebrate. Get a testimonial. Ask for a referral.
6. Document everything — this is your most valuable data.
experiments.kill_criteria: If your existing free users won't pay even $10/month after using the product, this is a serious product-market fit signal. Don't ignore it.
experiments.risk: Free user may churn when asked to pay. May lose the only user. That's okay — better to know now.
experiments.expected_outcome: First revenue (even $10) is a milestone. More importantly: real feedback on willingness to pay and product value.
experiments.minimum_viable_version: Send a message to your free user today asking for a 15-minute call.

experiments.name: Barber Referral Seed — turn early users into evangelists
experiments.hypothesis: If we offer early users 1 free month for every barber they refer who signs up, then each user will refer 1-2 barbers, because word-of-mouth is the #1 discovery method in the barber industry
steps: 1. Once you have 3+ active users, introduce a simple referral: 'Know another barber? If they sign up, you both get a free month.'
2. Make it dead simple: give each user a personal referral link
3. Follow up personally: 'Hey, do you know any other barbers who might want to try this?'
4. Track referral source for every new signup
experiments.kill_criteria: If users with referral incentive still won't refer, the product isn't creating enough value to talk about.

skills_needed: basic product feature to generate referral links

experiments.risk: Too early if you have <3 users. Don't build this before you have people to use it.
experiments.expected_outcome: Slow but organic growth through barber-to-barber recommendations.
experiments.minimum_viable_version: Just ask your existing user: 'Know any barbers who'd want to try this?' No tech needed.

experiments.name: Local Barber Supply Store Partnership
experiments.hypothesis: If we partner with 1-2 local barber supply stores to display a flyer or QR code, then we'll get 10+ scans and 2+ signups per month, because every barber visits their supply store regularly and trusts recommendations from there
steps: 1. Identify 2-3 barber supply stores in your area
2. Visit and offer: 'I built a booking app for barbers. Can I leave some flyers? Happy to give your customers a discount.'
3. Create a simple flyer: QR code, 'Book clients without making them download an app', free trial link
4. Offer the store owner a referral bonus or free feature
5. Track signups from QR code (use UTM parameters)
experiments.kill_criteria: If supply stores won't display your material, or 0 scans after 60 days, this channel isn't viable in your area.
experiments.risk: Store owners may not want to promote software. Low traffic stores won't generate scans.
experiments.expected_outcome: Small but steady local awareness channel. Builds legitimacy through physical presence.
experiments.minimum_viable_version: Visit 1 supply store this month and ask if you can leave 10 flyers.

then_try.name: Online Demo Sessions — 'Free 15-min booking setup for barbers'
then_try.hypothesis: If in-person demos aren't viable (wrong location, founder discomfort), offering free Zoom setup sessions to barbers found on Instagram/Facebook could produce similar validation results

then_try.name: Reddit r/Barber targeted engagement
then_try.hypothesis: If Facebook groups don't work (too spam-filtered, too competitive), Reddit r/Barber has 100K+ members and the founder already knows Reddit

anti_experiments.dont_do: Invest any time in SEO content or blog posts
anti_experiments.why: Your site is a SPA that Google can't crawl. Writing blog posts is pouring water into a bucket with no bottom. Fix the technical architecture first, THEN consider SEO.
anti_experiments.when_it_makes_sense: After implementing SSR/pre-rendering AND having 20+ pages indexed by Google

anti_experiments.why: With 0 paying customers, a <6% landing page conversion rate, and no social proof, paid ads will burn money. You'd be paying $5-15 per click to send people to a page that doesn't convert. Fix the funnel first.
anti_experiments.when_it_makes_sense: After 10+ paying customers, a conversion rate >15%, and at least 1 testimonial on the landing page

anti_experiments.why: You don't have enough users to know what features matter. Every hour coding is an hour not spent talking to barbers. The product is good enough to demo — the problem is nobody's seeing it.
anti_experiments.when_it_makes_sense: After 10+ users have given specific feature requests that are blocking adoption

anti_experiments.dont_do: Pitch to VCs or apply to accelerators
anti_experiments.why: With 0 revenue and 1 user, you won't get funded, and the process will consume weeks of time better spent on customer development.
anti_experiments.when_it_makes_sense: After $5K+/month revenue and a clear growth trajectory

anti_experiments.dont_do: Expand to med spas, nail salons, or other verticals
anti_experiments.why: You haven't proven you can win ONE barber. Spreading across verticals dilutes your already-thin resources and makes your messaging even more generic.
anti_experiments.when_it_makes_sense: After 50+ paying barber customers and organic pull from other verticals

anti_experiments.why: Too expensive, too broad, and at your stage, 1:1 conversations are infinitely more valuable than 1:many exposure. Walk into barbershops instead.
anti_experiments.when_it_makes_sense: After 20+ customers and a polished demo setup with social proof

resource_summary.notes: Wave 1 is intense (12 hrs/week across 4 experiments) but front-loaded with the directory blitz and homepage rewrite being one-time efforts. After week 2, Wave 1 drops to ~7 hrs/week (demos + Facebook engagement + user conversion calls). All experiments are $0 budget — time only.
